metadata.case_name: Chitpore Golabari Company Private Ltd. & Anr. v. Happy Homes Private Ltd.

facts.text: A building in Calcutta belonging to Chitpore Golabari Company Private Ltd. was let out under a written lease for 12 years commencing January 1, 1939, to Allen Berry Co. Ltd. Sub-letting prohibited without landlord's written consent.
After expiry of lease (December 31, 1950), Allen Berry continued to hold over the premises.
On August 12, 1953, Allen Berry served notice on landlord intimating intention to vacate premises on August 31, 1953, at 3:30 P.M. and requested delivery of possession.
By letter dated August 25, 1953, Allen Berry informed landlord that they did not intend to vacate on August 31, 1953, and cancelled the notice dated August 12, 1953.

By letter dated August 28, 1953, landlord's attorney informed Allen Berry that notice dated August 12, 1953, could not be withdrawn without mutual consent, as landlord had agreed to lease to Dunlop Rubber Co. India Ltd. from September 1953, and insisted on vacation.
On September 14, 1953, Allen Berry intimated holding over under Rent Control Act.
On February 10, 1954, landlord called upon Allen Berry to vacate by March 31, 1954.
Allen Berry failed to vacate; on May 7, 1954, sub-let part of ground floor (2100 sq. ft.) to Happy Homes P. Ltd.

Landlord instituted suit against Allen Berry for ejectment and mesne profits; settled on March 28, 1955, with consent decree stating: Allen Berry surrendered tenancy by notice August 12, 1953; handed possession of portion to landlord; landlord at liberty to retain or eject sub-tenant; sub-tenancy created without landlord's knowledge/consent.
Landlord sued Happy Homes in Calcutta High Court for possession and mesne profits.
Happy Homes resisted: (i) Allen Berry's tenancy not determined before sub-letting; (ii) even if determined, under West Bengal Rent Control Act 1950, became direct tenant.
P. Mitra J. decreed for landlord: possession and mesne profits Rs. 495/- p.m. from March 1, 1955.
During appeal pendency, landlord transferred premises to Calcutta Credit Corporation Ltd. (collectively landlords).
Division Bench of Calcutta High Court reversed trial decree, dismissed landlords' claim.

legal_issues.text: Whether the tenancy of Allen Berry stood determined by the notice dated August 12, 1953.
Whether, even if Allen Berry's tenancy determined, Happy Homes as sub-tenant became direct tenant under West Bengal Premises Rent Control Temporary Provisions Act, 1950.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notice of intention to quit dated August 12, 1953, could not be withdrawn unilaterally; tenancy determined on expiry; cannot be restored without mutual agreement creating fresh tenancy.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Transfer of Property Act, 1882, s. 111(h); Foa's General Law of Landlord & Tenant; Woodfall on Landlord & Tenant; Tayleur v. Wildin

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if notice defective, landlord accepted and acted upon it by refusing withdrawal and arranging new lease.
Statutory tenant (post-determination) has no estate/interest to sub-let; sub-tenant gets no protection under Rent Control Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: West Bengal Premises Rent Control Temporary Provisions Act, 1950; Anand Nivas Private Ltd. v. Anandji Kalyanji Pedhi

respondent_arguments.text: Tenant can withdraw notice of intention to quit before expiry under s. 113 TPA; notice not duly given under s. 111(h).
Even if tenancy determined, Allen Berry statutory tenant could sub-let; sub-tenant becomes direct tenant under ss. 12, 13 of Rent Control Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: West Bengal Premises Rent Control Temporary Provisions Act, 1950, ss. 2(11), 12, 13; Indra Kumar Karnani v. Atul Chandra Patitundi; Krishna Prosad Bose v. Smt. Sarajubala Dassi

court_reasoning.text: Notice to quit cannot be withdrawn without consent of party to whom given; tenancy determined on expiry unless mutual agreement for new tenancy. Principle from English law applies in India.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Landlord refused withdrawal and acted on notice by arranging new lease.

court_reasoning.text: Even defective notice determines tenancy if accepted by landlord; here landlord accepted by letter August 28, 1953.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Estoppel prevents tenant denying validity after acceptance.

court_reasoning.text: Statutory tenant has no estate/interest, merely personal protection; cannot sub-let or confer interest on sub-tenant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Tenant' in ss. 12(1)(c), 13(2) means contractual tenant, not statutory tenant.

court_reasoning.text: Sub-letting by statutory tenant forfeits protection; no statutory provision allows sub-tenant to step into shoes.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of Act protects contractual tenancies.

holdings.text: Tenancy of Allen Berry determined at 3:30 P.M. on August 31, 1953, by notice dated August 12, 1953, and landlord's acceptance.
Statutory tenant cannot sub-let; sub-tenant not entitled to become direct tenant under Rent Control Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Notice to quit cannot be withdrawn without consent; creates new agreement if continued.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anand Nivas Private Ltd. v. Anandji Kalyanji Pedhi Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Statutory tenant has no estate/interest, merely personal protection.
Statutory tenant cannot confer estate on sub-tenant; sub-tenant's right ends with statutory tenancy.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indra Kumar Karnani v. Atul Chandra Patitundi
precedents_cited.relevance: Covenant against sub-letting does not prevent sub-tenant claiming under s.13(2), but not authority for statutory tenant sub-letting.

precedents_cited.case_name: Krishna Prosad Bose v. Smt. Sarajubala Dassi
precedents_cited.relevance: Held statutory tenant can sub-let and sub-tenant protected under s.13(2); rejected by SC.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice to quit determines lease; cannot be withdrawn unilaterally; defective notice effective if accepted.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Premises Rent Control Temporary Provisions Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Protection against eviction; sub-letting by contractual tenant may allow sub-tenant to become direct tenant if conditions met; does not apply to statutory tenants.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; trial court's decree restored with modification that mesne profits payable from September 1, 1953, at Rs. 495/- per month till delivery of possession. Landlords entitled to costs in Supreme Court and High Court Division Bench.
outcome.relief_granted: Decree for possession and mesne profits from September 1, 1953, at Rs. 495/- p.m.; costs.
outcome.costs: Landlords entitled to costs in this Court and before Division Bench of High Court.

key_quotes.text: "A notice to quit cannot be waived for once a valid notice is given, the tenancy will inevitably be determined upon its expiration. But though the parties cannot waive the notice, they may nullify its operation as to quitting by agreeing upon a new tenancy."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains irrevocability of notice without consent.

key_quotes.text: "A statutory tenant has no estate or interest himself, and he cannot carve something out of nothing."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on inability of statutory tenant to sub-let.

key_quotes.text: "The expression 'tenant' in cl. (c) of s. 12(1) or in s. 13(2) must, in our judgment, mean a contractual tenant alone and not a statutory tenant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
